text: This is the tower of babel that the next gen general purpose language is attempting to replace. How many people actually know top to bottom a stack containing C++, Python, HTML, CSS, JS, Vue, SQL, Yaml, and Nomad? That is an awful lot of stuff to learn IMHO. In my Beads system I can replace the HTML/CSS/JS/Vue stack and Python and the database, so am making progress.  But interfacing with C++ is a no-go, as i am emitting either JS or AS3. Perhaps a Haxe target for desktop would allow C++ interfacing. There is a ton of code already written for mapping, and it is very technical and difficult to debug stuff. This is why so much inertia exists.

In my Beads system I can replace the HTML/CSS/JS/Vue stack and Python and the database, so am making progress.  But interfacing with C++ is a no-go, as i am emitting either JS or AS3. Perhaps a Haxe target for desktop would allow C++ interfacing. There is a ton of code already written for mapping, and it is very technical and difficult to debug stuff. This is why so much inertia exists.

text: >  One of the big questions every next-gen language has to face sooner or later, is: Is it a suitable replacement for any of the top 3 languages in use which are JavaScript, Java, and Python?

elements.text: One of the big questions every next-gen language has to face sooner or later, is: Is it a suitable replacement for any of the top 3 languages in use which are JavaScript, Java, and Python?

text: The last great programming language boom was circa 95 when those 3—as well as PHP and Ruby—arrived on the scene, and largely can be attributed to the arrival of the web.

elements.text: The last great programming language boom was circa 95 when those 3—as well as PHP and Ruby—arrived on the scene, and largely can be attributed to the arrival of the web.

text: I don't think you can "design" a language to replace any of those top 3. I think the only way they get replaced is if we see a similar external black swan event like the web.

elements.text: I don't think you can "design" a language to replace any of those top 3. I think the only way they get replaced is if we see a similar external black swan event like the web.

text: Personally I am very bullish we will see such an event, and I think it will be due to program synthesis/deep learning. So I think languages that are designed for human/AI co-authoring of programs could be breakout hits

elements.text: Personally I am very bullish we will see such an event, and I think it will be due to program synthesis/deep learning. So I think languages that are designed for human/AI co-authoring of programs could be breakout hits

text: (by very bullish I mean I'm 10% confident)
